Cavanagh Family Papers, 1857-2006

Finding aid created by
Thomas E. Powers, June 2006

did.abstract: Members of the Cavanagh family have resided in Yale, St. Clair County, Michigan since 1857. The collection was accumulated by Martha Cavanagh Cameron and consists of original and copied materials of various Cavanagh and Johnston family members.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Martha Cavanagh Cameron (donor no. 9665) and came to the library in April 2006.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Cavanagh Family Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Cavanagh family were early settlers to St. Clair County, Michigan, specifically to Brockway Township and the city of Yale. Andrew Cavanagh immigrated from Ireland to Ontario, Canada. In 1857, he came to Port Huron to work in the lumber business. While there, he looked for farm land to buy and where he could raise his family. In 1861, he purchased some property and moved to Brockway Township. He and his wife Annie McKay raised eight children.

Two of their sons, George and Justin were owners of the Princess movie theater in Yale, Michigan, purchased on September 18, 1915. In 1919, George bought out Justin's shares in the theater and continued for many years thereafter as sole proprietor.
On March 27, 1901, George Cavanagh had married Margaret Johnston. They had two sons, Herbert A. and Max H.

Another family member, George's nephew, Charles Andrew Cavanagh, was under-sheriff of St. Clair County. In 1934, he was killed in the line of duty by a companion of John Dillinger, recently escaped from jail.

scopecontent.p: The Cavanagh family papers have been arranged into an alphabetical series. The files have been arranged by name of family member with a few exceptions for general family and Yale related files. Of special note are the diaries of George Cavanagh, who was proprietor of the Princess movie theater in Yale, Michigan beginning in 1915.

did.unittitle: Cavanagh history, photographs, birth and death information

note.p: (include notebook with accounts and jottings, letter, etc.)
(see also oversize photograph of George Cavanagh as member of a group of rural mail carrier)
(descriptions of weather, operation of the movie theatre with comments on the movies and the stars, community events, and family matters)

note.p: (initially owned jointly by brothers George and Justin Cavanagh)
